> 
> This change will work for a brand new installation, which is primarily where you'd make the decision to use multipathing anyways, so this change is good for that. However, we also need to consider the scenario where its deployed and an operator decides to enable multipath after the fact. While its not the standard case (since use-multipath option defaults to true), we still do need to consider it.
> 
> One way to do this would be to add an @when('config.changed.use-multipath') handler to the cinder_purestorage_handlers.py class. It will also need to invoke the charm instance's send_storage_backend_data() method in order to pass the updated flag over to the principle charm.
> 
> As an aside, I noticed that the canonical-ci is not voting on this change so we'll need to look at the infrastructure to see what's going on as well.

Thanks for the feedback.
We've included the modification in the cinder_purestorage_handers.py file in patchset 2 in order to allow the operator to enable multipath after the initial deployment, based on your comments.

However, I'm not sure I understand why we would need to call the send_storage_backend_data() method as it seems that the subordinate flag (here use-multipath) is already correctly passed over to the principle. Please let me know if there is something missing there for me to fix.

Slightly off-topic, Canonical-ci pipeline is failing for python3.5 in what looks like to be a pip requirement issue. Is there any pending issue on the pipeline platform ?

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: Does the new cmd work for the various versions of k8s (1.18, 1.19, 1.20)? I believe on upgraded systems (stx.5 to stx.6), the user can be running any of these versions before working through the upgrade sequence.

Hello,

I have addressed all the comments in this review.
Please take another look.

Thanks.
I think we need a couple more checks added.

The current change isn't making things worse, so I'm going to approve it.

That said, I think it'd be better to log an explicit error message if the command fails so that we know where in the code it failed and maybe why.

Yes, it does Ghada.
It attempts to use the 'certs' command which is k8 ga (versions 1.20 > ) and fails over to 'alpha certs' which is the same command in experimental mode for older versions of kubernetes

sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/scripts/kube-cert-r.message: stderr probably shouldnt be sent to /dev/null? We dont want this to fail silently with no insight for someone looking into failures
True Sabeel, thanks for noticing. Fixed in latest patch.
I'm concerned here that we're not checking the return code of the command. What happens if something went wrong?
Sure, but errors can happen at any time.  So what happens if we get an error at line 30?

I check the return codes at line 23.

Either 'kubeadm certs' returns 0, without error and it's safe to use 'certs' command.

Or 'kubeadm certs' returns 1, with an error what means that 'certs' command is not supported and we need to use 'alpha certs' instead.

This is ensuring that will working for both versions greater than 1.20 and older like 1.18, 1.19 as well.

Line 30 will not fail because of my changes.
The check on line 24 ensures that CERT_CMD has the right command version for the system k8 installation.

Also the rest of the code does error handling already, which is part of the already existing code.

CERT_EXP_DATES is the starting point and it's expected that it has a list of dates for expiring certs. If the command fails this list will be empty the script will not proceed execution (line 35)

Lines following 67 are doing error checking as well.

Yes, even though we don't check the return code of this command, but on line 35, we do expect a valid time returned from the command. If no valid time returned, the time_left_s will be an empty string, and on line 66 the function will return 1 if time_left_s is empty, causing the whole script to raise a renewal fail alarm.

i think you should actully be inverting this and using lowercase not upper case to normalises.

as you noted in the comint libvirt is useing lower case and neutron will use lower case if it generates the mac.
it will only be upper case if the mac was propvided by the user.

lower case is a more common way to serialise mac adressis in other usages also.

So the thing is that all unit tests of nova has assumption of mac being in upper case. I didn't want to change that behaviour tbh but I can do that if you think it makes difference. I'm being fastidious here because it took me an annoyingly non-trivial amount of time to grok all of this, but isn't this normalization technically not necessary? It's the MAC we get from the libvirt XML, which is guaranteed to be lower case. All we need to do is normalize the mac from Neutron (aka what we have in migrate_data.vifs) to lower case. In fact, your unit test still passes if you remove this. Can we at least have a comment explaining that we're normalizing the libvirt XML MAC address, which is just to be extra safe?

Yeah, I agree that I added lower here just in case to be extra safe, as for some reason thought, that libvirt started normalizing macs starting from some version only. But it feels I was wrong. But anyway, I'd rather leave it as is ad adjusted comment only.

does this script need to be scoped to only run on non-subclouds ?

This should be run on only non-subclouds. The subclouds currently treat "registry.central" as an external registry to pull images from. When changing the registry on the central cloud, the subcloud will have access to the new images.

We currently don't explicitly prevent the user from setting up a subcloud that pulls from an external registry other than the central cloud's registry.central. I believe documenting that this only needs to be run on the central cloud in a dc setup would be sufficient here as well.

barbican_tempest_plugin/tests/rbac/v1/te.message:
So, we expect this to return a dict with "read", "write" etc. with no content?
Whats the expected return here given that a acl was never added, and can we document it?
This is already documented in the API reference: https://docs.openstack.org/barbican/latest/api/reference/acls.html#request-response-with-no-acl-defined
My question above is related to what we'd expect to see here if the acl is deleted.

You can think of DELETE-ing the ACL like "undefining" it.  A GET after a DELETE results in the same response as a GET before any ACL was defined.  So, in both cases the response we expect is what is documented in the API docs.

If you're curious why the asserts are different is because in the test above I just wanted to make sure that we could get a response, but in this test I'm making sure that the "users" was actually removed from the response.

Two ideas:

Option 1:

The object itself could have a complete flag.

So the shards are:

/path/to/object/001
/path/to/object/002

But the object itself:

/path/to/object

Could have data of "complete: True".

Option 2:

We delete the shards before writing them.  Then any incomplete write would produce invaled json data (I'm assuming all our data will be json), and then we can detect that on load with a json parse error.

This approach is too aggressive. As you see already, all horizon jobs which refer to upper-constraints.txt fail due to incompatible dependencies. It is not specific to horizon. The situation will be worse in horizon plugins. I think we should allow both 3.2 and 2.2 first, then update upper-consitrants, update lower-constraints in horizon plugins and finally bump the min Django version.

I proposed a way to make the transition of the Django version more smoothly in https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/horizon/+/815393 (as the first step to solve the current situation).
approving it fast so that we can make our gate job voting again asap.

I believe we need the following steps:
- 1. (already done) update global-requirements.txt to allow horizon to update requirements.txt to include Django 3.2. (Otherwise 
- 2. specify the required Django version which includes both 2.2 and 3.2 (at this point u-c uses 2.2)
- 3. update upper-constraints.txt in the requirements repo to use Django 3.2
- 4. bump the min version of Django in horizon
- (optionally) update non-primary-django tests to include non-primary versions of Django. (it seems you drops 2.2 support together when we support 3.2, so perhaps this step is not the case though.)

The above is what I did in past when we bump the Django minimum version.

However, https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/horizon/+/811412 directly updated the min version of Django to 3.2. Skipping almost all tests is not recommended.
already got two +2, self approving it to unblock the CI.

I'm not entirely sure that this check is correct. I think you might want:

  ((not self.lock or self.lock.is_still_valid()) and (not self.stop_event or not self.stop_event.is_set()))

The reason for this is if either the lock is no longer valid or the stop event is set we should return False because if we've lost one then we are no longer valid? But due to precedence I think this can evaluate to true if there is no lock at all but we have a stop event that has been set:

  >>> True or False and False or False
  True
